title-group.article-title: Multiple Fibroepithelial Polyps Arising from the Inferior Turbinate

author-notes.corresp: Hironobu Nishijima, MD, Department of Otolaryngology, Tokyo Teishin Hospital, 2-14-23 Fujimi, Chiyodaku, Tokyo, 102-8798 Email: nishijimahironobu@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2012
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

body.p: A77-year-old man presented with long periods of left-sided nasal obstruction and intermittent epistaxis. Nasal fibroscopy revealed an unusual, white, cauliflower-like, well-circumscribed, firm polypoidal mass arising from the vertebral portion of the left inferior turbinate (Figure 1). The surface of the multilocular polyps was lustrous. Computed tomography showed soft-tissue opacity with no enhancement that filled the left vestibule without any bony destruction.

caption.p: Endoscopic findings of tumor: a white cauliflower-like, polypoidal mass arising from the left inferior turbinate.

body.p: The mass measuring 2 cm was removed by an endoscopic inferior turbinectomy. Pathological examination showed small exophytic polyps with constrictions. Figure 2 shows the fibroepithelial polyps (FEPs) consisting of a fibrous lesion covered by pseudostratified cylindrical epithelium, surrounding a hemangioma. Compared with normal nasal polyps, FEPs had less infiltration of eosinophils, lymphocytes, and inflammatory cells. There was no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.

caption.p: The resected specimen revealed that the polyp was lined with normal epithelium and contained a hemangioma. Hematoxylin and eosin staining (original magnification: 10×).

body.p: The institutional review board of Tokyo Teishin Hospital approved this article.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: FEPs are localized polypoid lesions composed of varying amounts of stroma covered by epithelium. They are also known as acrochordons and present with a nonspecific, benign growth pattern. Their etiology is not well known. Chronic irritation, infection, hormonal imbalance, allergic factors, and developmental defects have been proposed.1

FEP is a common type of tumor in the skin, vulva, and the neck of the uterus, but it is rare in the nasal cavity, and no reports of a hemangioma inside the FEPs have been found. FEP shows a wide variety of findings in each lesion. As far as we know, the FEP from the main bronchus only shows similar findings to this case, such as multilocular polyps.2
FEP needs complete excision and histopathological examination because of the possibility of tissue metaplasia and the extremely low incidence of malignant transformation.3

sec.p: Hironobu Nishijima, substantial contributions to conception and design, drafting the article, final approval of the version to be published; Masato Yagi, substantial contributions to conception and design, revision of the article.
